userStories.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?

carousel_items: Don't take it if you have an allergy to aspirin since ibuprofen can cause a similar reaction.
Chlorpheniramine (the antihistamine ingredient in Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief) can make you sleepy, so avoid activities that require you to be fully alert until you know how it affects you.
While taking this, avoid alcohol and other drugs that make you drowsy.
Phenylephrine (the decongestant ingredient) can make you restless, so don't take it too close to bedtime.
Let your doctor know if your symptoms don't improve in a few days.
Don't use in kids age 12 years or younger.

basics.benefits_moa: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief is a combination medicine that treats cold and allergy symptoms. Ibuprofen is an NSAID that relieves swelling, pain, and fever. Chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine that treats runny nose and watery eyes. Phenylephrine is a decongestant that clears your sinuses.
basics.bottom_line: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief is an okay combination medicine to relieve pain and congestion. The antihistamine can make you sleepy and the decongestant can keep you awake, so it could affect you either way.
downsides: If you don't really need all of the medications in this combination, you're taking extra medicine and might have extra side effects for no reason.
Phenylephrine doesn't last as long as other decongestants like pseudoephedrine.
You shouldn't use it if you have high blood pressure.
The pain reliever (ibuprofen) can interact with other medications and make health problems like stomach bleeding and ulcers worse.
It's not safe to take ibuprofen if you're pregnant since it increases the risk of heart defects in babies.

downsides_processed.orig: If you don't really need all of the medications in this combination, you're taking extra medicine and might have extra side effects for no reason.
Phenylephrine doesn't last as long as other decongestants like pseudoephedrine.
You shouldn't use it if you have high blood pressure.
The pain reliever (ibuprofen) can interact with other medications and make health problems like stomach bleeding and ulcers worse.
It's not safe to take ibuprofen if you're pregnant since it increases the risk of heart defects in babies.

upsides: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief is a combination medicine that relieves multiple cold and allergy symptoms. It's good to use if you have a stuffy nose, sinus pressure, and pain.

The decongestant (phenylephrine) has fewer side effects than other decongestants like pseudoephedrine. It doesn't raise your blood pressure and heart rate as much, or cause as much trouble falling asleep.

upsides_processed.orig: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief is a combination medicine that relieves multiple cold and allergy symptoms. It's good to use if you have a stuffy nose, sinus pressure, and pain.

The decongestant (phenylephrine) has fewer side effects than other decongestants like pseudoephedrine. It doesn't raise your blood pressure and heart rate as much, or cause as much trouble falling asleep.

userStories.tip:
Made me drowsy but i couldn't sleep either.
.
brand name so its expensive, but it works and doesn't make you tired like benadryl
i wish i knew this before i started it
Take it before sleeping as prevention

drugs.name: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief

carousel_items_processed.orig: Don't take it if you have an allergy to aspirin since ibuprofen can cause a similar reaction.
Chlorpheniramine (the antihistamine ingredient in Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief) can make you sleepy, so avoid activities that require you to be fully alert until you know how it affects you.
While taking this, avoid alcohol and other drugs that make you drowsy.
Phenylephrine (the decongestant ingredient) can make you restless, so don't take it too close to bedtime.
Let your doctor know if your symptoms don't improve in a few days.
Don't use in kids age 12 years or younger.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief contains ibuprofen, which can cause serious problems including inflammation, bleeding, and ulcers in the stomach or intestines. The longer you take Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief, the higher the risk is. If you notice blood or a dark/black color in your stool, tell your doctor right away.
risk_factors: History of stomach bleeding or ulcers
Taking aspirin, NSAIDs, or blood thinners
Drinking more than 3 alcoholic beverages a day

description_processed.orig: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief contains ibuprofen, which can cause serious problems including inflammation, bleeding, and ulcers in the stomach or intestines. The longer you take Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief, the higher the risk is. If you notice blood or a dark/black color in your stool, tell your doctor right away.

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.
risk_factors: Taking other medicines that make you less alert

description_processed.orig: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief can harm unborn babies. Ibuprofen can increase the risk of a heart defect in an unborn baby if you take it during the last 3 months of pregnancy (last trimester). Phenylephrine can also be unsafe to take during the first 3 months of pregnancy (first trimester). Instead, it's safer to use a decongestant nasal spray for up to 3 days. Talk with your doctor or pharmacist about what's safe and will work best for you while pregnant.

description_processed.orig: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief can harm unborn babies. Ibuprofen can increase the risk of a heart defect in an unborn baby if you take it during the last 3 months of pregnancy (last trimester). Phenylephrine can also be unsafe to take during the first 3 months of pregnancy (first trimester). Instead, it's safer to use a decongestant nasal spray for up to 3 days. Talk with your doctor or pharmacist about what's safe and will work best for you while pregnant.

risks_warnings.title: Lower kidney function
risks_warnings.description: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief contains ibuprofen, an NSAID that can lower kidney function or cause damage. Taking the lowest dose for the shortest amount of time lowers your risk. Your doctor should check your kidney function if you take Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief for any amount of time.

description_processed.orig: Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief contains ibuprofen, an NSAID that can lower kidney function or cause damage. Taking the lowest dose for the shortest amount of time lowers your risk. Your doctor should check your kidney function if you take Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief for any amount of time.

risks_warnings.title: High blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: People taking Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief and MAO inhibitors together, or up to 14 days apart from each other, can experience very high blood pressure that can cause headaches and strokes. MAOI drugs are used to treat Parkinson's disease, depression, and other emotional conditions. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking MAO inhibitors and still want to use a cough medicine.

description_processed.orig: People taking Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief and MAO inhibitors together, or up to 14 days apart from each other, can experience very high blood pressure that can cause headaches and strokes. MAOI drugs are used to treat Parkinson's disease, depression, and other emotional conditions. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking MAO inhibitors and still want to use a cough medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Heart attack or stroke
risks_warnings.description: Phenylephrine can put additional stress on your heart. Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief also contains ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It can lower the benefit of low-dose aspirin (81 mg/day) in people taking it to prevent heart attacks and stroke, especially if taking both drugs together for a long time. Be careful when using it if you have a history of heart problems. Talk to your doctor if another option might be better for you.

description_processed.orig: Phenylephrine can put additional stress on your heart. Advil Allergy and Congestion Relief also contains ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It can lower the benefit of low-dose aspirin (81 mg/day) in people taking it to prevent heart attacks and stroke, especially if taking both drugs together for a long time. Be careful when using it if you have a history of heart problems. Talk to your doctor if another option might be better for you.

carousel_items: You need to show an ID to buy Advil Allergy Sinus in the drugstore because it contains pseudoephedrine.
Take it after eating to avoid getting an upset stomach.
Don't take it with alcohol or other drugs that make you sleepy.
Can cause an irregular or fast heartbeat, and can raise your blood pressure.
Be careful taking Advil Allergy Sinus if you have a history of bleeding problems or ulcers since it can make them worse.

basics.benefits_moa: Advil Allergy Sinus is a combination medicine to treat allergy and cold symptoms. Ibuprofen (an NSAID) relieves swelling, pain, and fever. Pseudoephedrine (a decongestant) clears your sinuses. Chlorpheniramine (an antihistamine) treats nasal allergy symptoms.
basics.bottom_line: Advil Allergy Sinus is good for multiple allergy and cold symptoms, but check to be sure you really need all of its ingredients.
downsides: If you don't really need all of the medications in this combination, you'd be taking extra medicine and can have extra side effects for no reason.
The pain reliever (ibuprofen) can interact with other medications and make health problems like stomach bleeding and ulcers worse.
It's not safe to take ibuprofen if you're pregnant since it increases the risk of heart defects in babies.
Pseudoephedrine, the decongestant in Advil Allergy Sinus, can make your heart race or make you feel anxious and restless.

downsides_processed.orig: If you don't really need all of the medications in this combination, you'd be taking extra medicine and can have extra side effects for no reason.
The pain reliever (ibuprofen) can interact with other medications and make health problems like stomach bleeding and ulcers worse.
It's not safe to take ibuprofen if you're pregnant since it increases the risk of heart defects in babies.
Pseudoephedrine, the decongestant in Advil Allergy Sinus, can make your heart race or make you feel anxious and restless.

upsides: Advil Allergy Sinus is a combination medicine that relieves allergy and cold symptoms. It's good to use if you have a runny nose, watery eyes, sneezing, headache, congestion, sore throat, or fever.
Ibuprofen (a pain reliever) is more effective than acetaminophen at lowering fever and relieving sinus pain.
Chlorpheniramine makes you less tired than other antihistamines.
Pseudoephedrine (a decongestant) clears nose congestion to help you breathe better.

upsides_processed.orig: Advil Allergy Sinus is a combination medicine that relieves allergy and cold symptoms. It's good to use if you have a runny nose, watery eyes, sneezing, headache, congestion, sore throat, or fever.
Ibuprofen (a pain reliever) is more effective than acetaminophen at lowering fever and relieving sinus pain.
Chlorpheniramine makes you less tired than other antihistamines.
Pseudoephedrine (a decongestant) clears nose congestion to help you breathe better.

carousel_items: Starts working in 30 minutes.
You need to show an ID to buy Advil Cold and Sinus in the drugstore because it contains pseudoephedrine.
Don't take it if you have an allergy to aspirin since ibuprofen can cause a similar reaction.
Take it after eating to avoid getting an upset stomach.
Can cause an irregular or fast heartbeat, and can raise your blood pressure.
Be careful taking Advil Cold and Sinus if you have a history of bleeding problems or ulcers since it can make them worse.
Talk to your doctor if symptoms don't get better in 1 week.

basics.benefits_moa: Advil Cold and Sinus is a combination medicine that relieves cold symptoms and sinus pressure. Ibuprofen (an NSAID) relieves pain and reduces fever. Pseudoephedrine (a decongestant) clears your sinuses.
basics.bottom_line: Advil Cold and Sinus is a good combination medicine to relieve pain and congestion, but it's more medicine than you need if you only have one symptom.
downsides: If you don't need both of the medications in this combination, you'd be taking extra medicine and can have extra side effects for no reason.
The pain reliever (ibuprofen) can interact with other medications and make health problems like stomach bleeding and ulcers worse.
It's not safe to take ibuprofen if you're pregnant since it increases the risk of heart defects in babies.
Pseudoephedrine, the decongestant in Advil Cold and Sinus, can make your heart race or make you feel anxious and restless.

downsides_processed.orig: If you don't need both of the medications in this combination, you'd be taking extra medicine and can have extra side effects for no reason.

It's not safe to take ibuprofen if you're pregnant since it increases the risk of heart defects in babies.
Pseudoephedrine, the decongestant in Advil Cold and Sinus, can make your heart race or make you feel anxious and restless.

upsides: Advil Cold and Sinus is a combination medicine that relieves cold symptoms. It's good to use if you have congestion, sore throat, headache, or fever.
Ibuprofen (a pain reliever) is more effective than acetaminophen at lowering fever and relieving sinus pain.
Pseudoephedrine (a decongestant) clears nose congestion to help you breathe better.

Contains acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol or APAP. Taking too much can cause liver failure and death. Don't take more than what's recommended on the package or with other Tylenol-containing products.
Follow age-specific dosing instructions on how much to take.
Let your doctor know if your symptoms don't improve in a few days.

basics.benefits_moa: Tylenol Sinus is a combination medicine that treats cold and allergy symptoms. Acetaminophen relieves pain and reduces fever. Phenylephrine is a decongestant that clears your sinuses.
basics.bottom_line: Tylenol Sinus is a good combination medicine to relieve pain and congestion. Be careful to not take too much acetaminophen (APAP) each day.
downsides: If you don't really need all of the medications in this combination, you're taking extra medicine and might have extra side effects for no reason.
Phenylephrine doesn't last as long as other decongestants like pseudoephedrine.
You shouldn't use it if you have high blood pressure.
To avoid hurting your liver, you need to keep track of the total amount of acetaminophen (APAP) you are taking since it is a very common ingredient in pain and cold/flu combination medicines.

downsides_processed.orig: If you don't really need all of the medications in this combination, you're taking extra medicine and might have extra side effects for no reason.
Phenylephrine doesn't last as long as other decongestants like pseudoephedrine.
You shouldn't use it if you have high blood pressure.
To avoid hurting your liver, you need to keep track of the total amount of acetaminophen (APAP) you are taking since it is a very common ingredient in pain and cold/flu combination medicines.

upsides: Tylenol Sinus is a combination medicine that relieves multiple cold symptoms. It's good to use if you have a stuffy nose, a headache, and pain.

The decongestant (phenylephrine) has fewer side effects than other decongestants like pseudoephedrine. It doesn't raise your blood pressure and heart rate as much, or cause as much trouble falling asleep.
The pain reliever (acetaminophen) is easier on your stomach and has fewer drug interactions than to other pain medications like aspirin or ibuprofen.

The pain reliever (acetaminophen) is easier on your stomach and has fewer drug interactions than to other pain medications like aspirin or ibuprofen.

drugs.name: Tylenol Sinus

carousel_items_processed.orig: Starts working in 30 minutes.
Phenylephrine (the decongestant ingredient) can make you restless, so don't take it too close to bedtime.

Contains acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol or APAP. Taking too much can cause liver failure and death. Don't take more than what's recommended on the package or with other Tylenol-containing products.
Follow age-specific dosing instructions on how much to take.
Let your doctor know if your symptoms don't improve in a few days.

names_brand: Tylenol Sinus Congestion and Pain Daytime

risks_warnings.title: Liver damage
risks_warnings.description: Tylenol Sinus contains acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol or APAP, and is a common ingredient in many other over-the-counter medicines. Taking too much acetaminophen causes liver damage that can be permanent and life-threatening. In case of an overdose, call your local Poison Control Center and get medical attention immediately.
risk_factors: Drinking more than 2 alcoholic beverages a day

description_processed.orig: Tylenol Sinus contains acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol or APAP, and is a common ingredient in many other over-the-counter medicines. Taking too much acetaminophen causes liver damage that can be permanent and life-threatening. In case of an overdose, call your local Poison Control Center and get medical attention immediately.

risks_warnings.title: High blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: People taking Tylenol Sinus and MAO inhibitors together, or up to 14 days apart from each other, can experience very high blood pressure that can cause headaches and strokes. MAOI drugs are used to treat Parkinson's disease, depression, and other emotional conditions. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking MAO inhibitors and still want to use a cough medicine.

description_processed.orig: People taking Tylenol Sinus and MAO inhibitors together, or up to 14 days apart from each other, can experience very high blood pressure that can cause headaches and strokes. MAOI drugs are used to treat Parkinson's disease, depression, and other emotional conditions. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking MAO inhibitors and still want to use a cough medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Tylenol Sinus can harm unborn babies. Phenylephrine can be unsafe to take during the first 3 months of pregnancy (first trimester). Instead, it's safer to use a decongestant nasal spray for up to 3 days. Talk with your doctor or pharmacist about what's safe and will work best for you while pregnant.

Instead, it's safer to use a decongestant nasal spray for up to 3 days. Talk with your doctor or pharmacist about what's safe and will work best for you while pregnant.
